I also recall that Hungary had a unique system called the Golden Liberty, which was a set of laws that limited the power of the king and granted more rights to the nobility. This system was established in the 13th and 14th centuries, and it included provisions where the nobles could elect the king, but only from certain families. So during the Golden Liberty period, it seems like the nobles, who were landowners, did have a say in who their ruler was. However, after the death of Louis I in 1382, there was a period known as the "Crisis of Succession." The nobles elected Charles of Luxembourg as king, but later Mary of Hungary and the Habsburgs got involved, leading to conflicts. This period shows that even in the later medieval times, the nobility could influence or elect the ruler, though it wasn't always straightforward. After the Battle of Mohács in 1526, which was a major defeat against the Ottoman Empire, Hungary was effectively split into two parts: the Habsburg-ruled area (Royal Hungary) and the Ottoman-occupied territory. From then on, the Habsburgs took over, and the elective monarchy aspect probably diminished as the Habsburgs inherited the throne through marriage rather than election. So, putting it all together, it seems that in the early and certain periods of the Kingdom of Hungary, landowners (nobles) did have the ability to elect their ruler, especially during the Golden Liberty era. However, this wasn't a continuous practice throughout the entire history of the kingdom, and over time, the system evolved into a hereditary monarchy, especially after the Habsburgs took over. Therefore, the answer is yes, landowners did elect their rulers at certain times in the Kingdom of Hungary.
</think>

Yes, in certain periods of the Kingdom of Hungary, particularly during the early medieval era and the period of the Golden Liberty (13th-14th centuries), landowners, who were part of the nobility, had the ability to elect their rulers. This elective system was significant during the Golden Liberty, where nobles could choose the king from specific families. However, this practice evolved over time, especially after the 16th century when the Habsburgs inherited the throne, leading to a hereditary monarchy. 

<answer>yes</answer>
